Navlibe works as an agricultural laborer. Agriculture has been a family tradition for her and her husband, a job that has been passed down through generations. But the income that she currently makes is barely sufficient to meet the household expenses. She is left with a meager savings of Rs. 4000, insufficient to provide for the future of her five children. Therefore, she intends to use her share of the enterprise loan to buy more fertilizers and seeds, so that she can grow varied kinds of crops in her field. There is a high demand for corn, tomatoes, onions, garlic, and ginger. So she will grow these crops and sell the produce. The better quality seeds and fertilizers she will purchase with the loan will guarantee a high yield, one that will help her in increasing the income and bringing financial stability.

The other group members are in a similar socio-economic situation. Kamliben and Shardaben will use their share of the loan to develop their respective microenterprises of agriculture and bamboo products. 

Your loan will not just help Navlibe and her group to expand their small businesses. Your timely support will ultimately result in ensuring good education for their children. Along with this, it will also brace them up for emergencies. After investing your loan in her microenterprise, Navlibe stands to increase her savings to Rs. 6000 a month; a 50% increase. She will also have Rs. 4000 each month to reinvest in the growth of her business. Over a period of time, she will be able to guarantee that her five children get a complete education. Having had no education herself due to her family’s poverty, this is a tremendous opportunity for Navlibe, and she is particularly grateful for it.

loans.use: to buy more seeds and fertilizers for her business of agricultural production

loans.name: Rikki Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Chuniben, the group leader (woman in the center), hails from Dahod district in Gujarat. She runs her own small petty shop business to contribute to her family’s income of Rs. 7000. She has three teen-aged children, and her income of Rs. 4,000 helps her to provide a better quality of life, education, and healthcare to her family. But her income is just sufficient with a meager savings of Rs. 2000. Educating three children will need a lot more than these savings. She now hopes to expand her microenterprise by increasing the items she sells so that she can increase her income.

She plans to buy additional items like Vaseline, ghee, butter, sugar, and oil in larger quantities. This will help her increase her customer base and provide more goods to increase her income. But, local banks will not provide the microfinance Chuniben needs to expand her small business. So Chuniben has joined with four other local women who run similar small businesses and want to expand their microenterprises. Her group comprises of Sushilaben and Sunitaben, who run their petty shops, and Manjuben and Ramilaben, who run their dress material shops. Chuniben and her group seek to crowdfund the Rs. 50,000 they need to expand their small businesses. 

Your loan will help these women to expand their businesses, increase their incomes, and provide a better quality of life for their children. In Chuniben’s case, this investment will help her business net an additional Rs. 6000 each month. She will take Rs. 2000 home to add to her savings, and will use the rest to continue growing her small business. Having never been to school, educating her own three children is her most important goal. She is grateful for this opportunity to achieve it.

loans.use: to purchase bulk stock of Vaseline, sugar, ghee, incense, oil, and rice and grow her petty shop microenterprise

loans.name: Soha Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Samim (at center) hails from Dahod, a small town in eastern Gujarat. At 47, she runs a small tailoring microenterprise, catering to her local community. She earns Rs. 4000 a month, supplementing her husband’s income of Rs. 5000, which she sets aside entirely in savings. Together, they are working to build a corpus that will sustain them in their old age. Recognizing that prices will continue to rise and they may encounter home repairs and increased medical expenses over the years, Samim wants to grow her microenterprise into a self-sustaining source of income that will provide for their needs. 

Buying a new sewing machine will help Samim improve her productivity. She wants to take on more orders and sew dresses, shirts, sari falls and interlocks, and curtains. Over the ongoing festive and auspicious wedding season, in particular, she receives a lot of orders. Having a better machine will help her to take these orders on and enjoy a boost in business and customers. She stands to net an increase of Rs. 6000 in monthly revenue and profit. Of this, she plans to save Rs. 2000 for herself and invest the rest in further developing her business towards self-sustenance. 

To access the microfinance she needs to buy the sewing machine, Samim has formed a group with four other like-minded women: Sidunnisa and Sahjaha are also tailors, and Kausharbibi and Saminaben sell accessories and ornaments, locally known as "cutlery." Her group members need to grow their businesses and earn the extra income so they can provide for their children’s education and future. Your loan will help these four hardworking women realize their goals of financial independence, financial stability, and a better future for their children and families. Samim expresses their gratitude for your support, and is thankful for this opportunity.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine and grow her tailoring microenterprise

loans.name: Swati Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Bhartiben (third from left in the picture) is a tailor by profession in Chandkheda, Gujarat. She leads this group of hardworking local women entrepreneurs. At 47 years old and the eldest among them, she draws on her experience to advise, encourage, and support her group. Bhartiben formed the group to avail herself of the microfinance necessary to grow her tailoring business. 

Her family of four lives off a combined income of Rs. 12,000; Bhartiben’ tailoring microenterprise contributes to a fourth of this income. A diligent steward of their finances, Bhartiben stretches this meager amount to cover their living expenses, and saves Rs. 5000 each month. These savings help tide them over during financial crunches, and provide for the education of their child. But they will hold inadequate in the long run. 

Bhartiben will be able to earn more if she expands her business by purchasing a new, efficient sewing machine. Since she typically sews sari falls and interlocks, she wants to buy and stock these materials in bulk, so she can take on more orders. A skilled seamstress, she also wants to stock up on dress materials and make and sell ready garments. These measures can help her increase her income by Rs. 5000 a month, adding to her savings and leaving enough to reinvest in her small business.

All these purchases need capital. Like her, the other members of this group, Ushaben, Mayurika and Renuka, seek funding to grow their stationery shop, beauty parlor, and sari business respectively. Together, they seek a loan of Rs. 40,000 to boost their microenterprises. Your loan will help these women take a crucial step toward building their financial independence, and bringing happiness and cheer to themselves and their loved ones. For Bhartiben, who dropped out after primary school due to her parents’ poverty, this is a huge opportunity to ensure her child gets a complete education. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine, sari fall and interlock materials, and dress materials for the growth of her tailoring microenterprise

loans.name: Kabir Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Anitaben (second from left), a 38-year-old mother of four from Chandkheda in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, runs a provisional store. She didn't get the opportunity to attend middle school, and somehow completed her primary level education. But she had the potential and the business acumen to start up a provisional store. Further, this initiative was more of a necessity. Her husband's income is barely sufficient to meet their household expenses, which tends to be a sum of Rs. 5000. She tries to supplement to his income by working very hard to earn this amount. The remaining Rs. 3000 that her husband earns, she sets aside entirely as savings for her children’s education. 

Now, to guarantee that all four of her children can access public college, she wants to expand her microbusiness further. She intends to buy a lot of stock in bulk so that she can cater to more customers. Items like biscuits, chocolates, snacks, and chips sell fast in her residential area that is also close to developing business localities. By purchasing them in bulk, her shop stands to improve profit margins and revenue, netting an extra Rs. 10,500 each month. With the amount, Anitaben can almost double her savings and reinvest in the growth of her microenterprise. 

Local banks do not provide financial assistance to micro-entrepreneurs like Anitaben. So she has formed a Joint Liability Group along with three other industrious women, who aspire to live a better life and to educate their children. With the loan, Sunitaben, Shardaben, and Chandrakalaben will also expand their respective business of selling handbags, saris, and making and selling handicrafts. 

Your loan will help ensure financial stability for Anitaben and her group members. This will help them fulfill their dreams of sending their children to college. Further, it will build up their confidence and self-esteem tremendously. Anitaben conveys the gratitude of the entire group for your support in their endeavors to build a better life.

loans.use: To stock up in bulk on items, such as biscuits, chocolates, chips, and snacks, for her provisional store

loans.name: Ajija Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Ajijabibi (at center in the picture) lives with her husband and four children in Dahod, a small town in eastern Gujarat near the state’s borders with Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh. 

To cope with the additional expenditure of her children’s education, Ajijabibi has been running a petty shop, a small departmental store, out of her house. She purchases her stock from the wholesale market and sells it for a small profit in her shop.  She earns Rs. 2000 a month, and saves the entire sum along with an extra Rs. 2500 from the income her husband brings in. Their savings and the income from her small business are critical in keeping her family financially afloat. 

However, Ajijajbibi needs to explore options to grow her income and savings. This is crucial if she must stabilize her family’s finances while also fulfilling her hopes of putting all her four children through public college. Business at her shop has been good enough, and there certainly is an extra demand that she currently cannot fulfill due to limited stock. If she had more stock, she could meet more of her customers’ demand. The main challenge she faces is the lack of funds to invest in and scale up her small business. The bulk purchase of stock requires hefty investments, which she is unable to afford. On the plus side, buying in bulk will let her negotiate a better purchase rate. She will also save transportation costs she would have otherwise incurred by making multiple trips. Overall, she can net an extra Rs. 5000 per month in increased income and profits.

Seeing the huge immediate and long-term benefits, Ajijabibi formed a group with four other local women in similar circumstances, all of them seeking to grow their own microenterprises. Hamidabibi, Sultanabibi, and Najmabibi sell toys, and Rahisabibi runs a poultry business. They are seeking a group loan amount of Rs. 75,000. 

Your loan will help Ajijabibi make an investment that will more than double her contribution to her family’s income. The increased income will also leave her with an extra Rs. 2500 each month to reinvest in the growth and development of her small petty shop. She is grateful for this opportunity to improve her life and that of her children.

loans.use: to stock up on biscuits, chocolates, toys, wafers, peanuts, and gram to serve more customers at her petty shop

loans.name: Piran Pir Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Twenty-two year-old Raziya (second from right in the photo) is among the growing number of women entrepreneurs in the state of Gujarat who can simply not be ignored. Besides sustaining her family financially, Raziya ardently intends to stand on her own feet. Educated only until the primary school level due to difficult circumstances, she is intent on achieving financial independence and stability for herself before she gets married. She lives with her family of four, contributing 40% of their monthly income by selling vegetables for a living. 

Raziya buys vegetables at wholesale rates from the main market and sells them locally, earning Rs. 8,000 a month. Her family collectively saves Rs. 4,000, which goes towards medical and other emergency expenses, and in the long run, to improve their standard of living. 

Working towards achieving her goal of financial independence and to uplift her family out of poverty, Raziya has decided to capitalize on the growing local demand for fresh vegetables at affordable rates. She wants to buy in bulk popular vegetables like eggplant, tomatoes, potatoes, chilies, and okra. Purchasing in bulk will help her source the produce at better rates and also cater to more customers. This move can increase her enterprise income by Rs. 10,000, more than double her current income. Of this, she plans to reinvest 80% every month towards growing her business further. 

To achieve these goals, young Raziya formed the Piran Pir Mahila Mandal group with three other local women microentrepreneurs. Together, they seek to crowdfund Rs. 60,000 in microfinance. Raziya will use the funds to buy more stock, as planned, for her vegetable selling microenterprise, and the other three members, Virbai, Jenatbai, and Memunabai, will similarly invest in growing their respective microenterprises of tailoring, selling clothes, and running a petty shop. Your loan will help Raziya and her group of hardworking and diligent women to progress towards their goals of financial independence and stability.

loans.use: To buy vegetables like tomatoes, okra, potatoes, eggplant, and chilies in bulk to sell

loans.name: Sakhi Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Purbai, the group leader (first from right in the picture), lives in Gandhidham, in the Kutch district of Gujarat. She owns a small cloth and garment selling business. She buys dresses, dress materials, scarves, stoles, curtains, T-shirts, etc., from the wholesale markets and sells them locally for a profit. Her microenterprise brings home an income of 4,000 Indian rupees (INR) a month, contributing to 25% of her family’s income. She uses this income to cover expenses for her family of five, including education costs for her two teenaged children. 

Purbai’s lack of education is her driving force in ensuring that her children have access to what she could not. Her family manages to save 2,000 INR a month, but this is not sufficient to ensure that her two children get a better life than her own. 

Purbai now seeks a loan to grow her small cloth and garments business by buying extra stock. Bulk buying will allow her to negotiate better purchase rates with her suppliers and make a profit. Having more stock, she will also be able to cater to the additional demand she sees each month. This will especially help boost her income during the festive and auspicious wedding season in India. She stands to net an additional 10,000 INR a month, which makes a huge difference to Purbai. She will be able to more than double her income with the potential to save 8,000 INR a month. It will also leave a substantial sum each month to reinvest in her business, making her business a sustainably growing income source. 

Purbai comes together with a group of women like herself to seek a loan of 40,000 INR towards growing their microenterprises. Sonidevi, like Purbai, has her own cloth business; Muniben runs a petty shop; and Sita tailors clothes. Your loan will empower these four women’s households and businesses, allowing their children access to a good education and a better life. Purbai is grateful for your support in achieving her goal of educating her child.

loans.use: To buy dresses, dress materials, scarves, stoles, curtains, and T-shirts for her garments and cloth microenterprise

loans.name: Huseni Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Hajraben, the group leader (lady in the center), hails from the Surendranagar district in Gujarat. She runs her own small clothing microenterprise to increase her family income. She purchases clothes from the wholesale market and sells them at a profit locally. Her income of 4,000 Indian rupees (INR) helps her to provide a better quality of life and health care for her family. But her income is just sufficient to contribute to their meager savings of 6,000 INR, which tides them over financially during medical and other emergencies. Married and living with her in-laws, 27-year-old Hajraben wants to start saving more so she can start her own family. She now hopes to expand her microenterprise by increasing the items she sells so that she can increase her income. 

Hajraben plans to buy additional items like jeans, dress materials, saris, leggings, etc., in bulk. These garments sell with a high demand among her customers. This will help her increase her customer base and provide more goods to increase her income by 6,000 INR a month. She cannot, however, fund these expansion plans through her own savings, and local banks do not provide access to microfinance either. So, Hajraben has joined with four other local women who run similar small businesses and want to expand their enterprise. This group of women, comprised of Jubiben, Roshanben, Fatmaben, and Sherabanuben, run their own clothing shops. 

Hajraben and her group seek to crowdfund the 75,000 INR they need to expand their small businesses. Your loan will help them to diversify and bulk up their inventories of garments, such as jeans, dress materials, sari, leggings, etc., which are in demand, and grow their businesses. 

Your loan will help these women to increase their incomes and provide a better quality of life for their children.

loans.use: To buy inventory like dresses, jeans, stoles, saris, and leggings to expand her clothes selling microenterprise

loans.name: Bukhari Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Sherbanu (second from right, in black) runs her own masonry microenterprise in the small town of Adipur in the Kutch district of Gujarat in western India. She is a part of the local construction industry and mostly makes centering structures, which she can then rent out to building masons. These structures are used when building arches, vaults, etc., during construction. Sherbanu makes these by fixing a few plane wooden blocks supported by bamboo poles. The rent is decided based upon the square feet area of the structure. One structure can be used three or four times to build the roof in construction. After this, the old structure cannot be used anymore. So, after renting a structure out three to four times, Sherbanu cannot make any more money off it and has to build a new structure. If Sherbanu could increase the number of structures she makes and rents out at a time, she could almost double the money her small business brings in. 

Sherbanu’s family could certainly use the extra income and savings as she has two teenagers and one primary school-aged child to raise and educate. With a family of six, their current savings of 5,000 Indian rupees (INR) a month will not be able to provide for the children’s education. To put this plan to earn more into action, Sherbanu needs capital to buy bamboos, ropes, wooden blocks, and some accessories to build more centering structures. She will also buy other materials to support her construction business. 

So, Sherbanu formed the Bukhari Mahila Mandal Group with three other confident and diligent local women microentrepreneurs. This is a joint liability group through which they hope to access financial assistance and develop their respective microenterprises: Aaisa runs a petty shop, Roshan runs an embroidery business, and Sakina operates an auto repair service. Collectively, they seek to crowdfund microfinance of 60,000 INR as a loan.

Sherbanu, like her group members, could not attend school due to difficult circumstances back then but dreams of providing education and a better future for her children. Your loan will help change their lives to a huge extent. With your support, Sherbanu will be able to increase her monthly income by 50% and double her family’s savings. Not only will your loan help to improve the family’s standard of living and guarantee education for her children, but it will also build Sherbanu’s self-confidence as she reinvests part of her increased profits towards further growth. 

Sherbanu is grateful for this opportunity to improve her life.

loans.use: To buy bamboo, ropes, and other raw materials for her masonry microenterprise

loans.name: Sitaram Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Ramilaben (standing in the center of the photo) from Gangordi, in the Dahod district of Gujarat, has been involved in the traditional business of agricultural production for a very long time. Agriculture has always been the main source of livelihood for her entire family. But her household income tends to be a small sum of Rs. 11,000. This proves to be barely sufficient to take care of the needs of her family of six. To improve their situation, she has decided to grow multiple varieties of crops, one that will not only help in increasing her income, but will also help in successfully meeting the household expenses. 

Ramilaben has formed a group along with two other women. Both Methaliben and Lilaben too share the same story. All of them hail from the rural Gangardi in Dahod, Gujarat. Further, what binds them together is their dream to give the best of education to their children. None of them could go to school. But, like Ramilaben, they wish for better things for their children. They are collectively seeking a microfinance loan of Rs. 36,000. 

Your loan will help Ramilaben to buy seeds and fertilizers for growing varied crops like corn, onions, tomatoes, garlic, and ginger. She will also be able to buy and rent implements that will help her sow and harvest these crops in a better way. This, in turn will increase her agricultural production to a considerable extent, almost doubling her contribution to her family’s income. She will enjoy an increase of Rs. 7,000 per month in her agricultural profits. Some of this money will be used to improve the business continuously, making it financially self-sustainable. Your loan will thus help Ramilaben and the two women in her group to bring to fruition their dreams of financial stability and better lives for their families. It will help them guarantee access to a full education for their children. They are grateful for this opportunity, and are determined to do well.

loans.use: To buy seeds, implements, and fertilizers for her business of agricultural production

loans.name: Shirdi Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Jaylaxmi Tejarao (at the center in the picture) from Gandhidham, in the Kutch district of Gujarat, rises early each morning, buys fresh produce and ingredients, and cooks large quantities of healthy, hearty meals. She then delivers packed lunches to her many local customers. 

Jaylaxmi is no stranger to facing challenges in trying to create a sustainable livelihood for her family. But these challenges are made even more difficult by the lack of access to financial credit in times of need. Her tiffin service business has had limited growth due to the unavailability of much required funds. Together with her husband, Jaylaxmi manages to save just about Rs. 4,000 per month, which puts them in a bind during emergencies and critical situations. While Jaylaxmi saves her entire income, she has to spend her husband’s entire salary of Rs. 8,000 to cover the living expenses for her family of three. With rising costs, and their hope of starting a family of their own, they need to save more, and it’s crucial that Jaylaxmi expands her tiffin services business. With timely financial support, she can capitalize on the increased demand for her services and her enterprise can bring in an additional Rs. 9,000 each month. 

The success of Milaap and its field partner Prayas in reaching out to under-served communities in Gujarat has spelled relief for women like Jaylaxmi. Along with four other local women, she has formed a joint liability group called Shirdi Mahila Mandal. Together they seek a loan of Rs. 75,000. Jaylaxmi, Janakamma, Navina, and Parvati will use their share of the amount in growing their tiffin business, while Padma plans to stock up the items in her snack business. With their monthly incomes from this expansion expected to go up to about Rs. 10,000. 

Your loan will help Jaylaxmi develop her business into a sustainable source of income for when she ages. It will also provide a financially stable future for five families.

loans.use: To grow her tiffin service business and deliver more packed lunches for increased income

loans.name: Ram Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Chelaben (at the center in the picture) hails from Dahod, a small town and important transport hub in eastern Gujarat near the state’s borders with Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh. She runs a petty shop, selling small quantities of groceries and products for daily use, such as vaseline, sugar, oil, ghee, incense, and rice, to customers in her neighborhood. The Rs. 5,000 she earns contributes to a third of her family’s income, and she saves this entire amount. Her shop sees a steady stream of business, though stocks are often low and there is little variety. This means she has to, sometimes, turn away customers and the opportunity to earn more. 

Chelaben and her family could certainly use the extra money to build a financially stable future and improve their living conditions. If she invests in additional quantities of stock, Chelaben’s shop can net an increased profit of Rs. 8,000 each month. Diligent with her finances despite receiving only a primary education, she plans to reinvest some of this to make her business self-sustaining, and will use the rest to grow her own savings by almost 40%. Seeking to finance these plans, she has formed a group with four other local women micro entrepreneurs, Anitaben, Gitaben, and Senaben, who also run their own petty shops, and Sumiben, who sells vegetables. All of them are married with children, and want to grow their businesses to earn more and fund their children’s education. 

The main challenge all of them face is the lack of funds to invest in and scale up their businesses. Despite the businesses running successfully, they are unable to purchase stocks in higher quantities since this requires additional investment which they do not possess. Prayas (Milaap’s partner) works with women-entrepreneurs like Chelaben and her group to help them realize the full potential of their businesses by helping them crowdfund loans to scale-up operations. A loan of Rs. 75,000 will help them purchase the stock necessary to grow their microenterprises. Your loan will help them realize their goals of financial independence, stability, and education for their children.

loans.use: To increase the stock of vaseline, sugar, oil, ghee, incense, and rice she will sell at her petty shop to increase profits

loans.name: Chamunda Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Rupaben (standing at the center of the photo) has been running her tea stall in rural Gangardi in Dahod, Gujarat, for quite a long time in order to supplement her family's income. She is an industrious woman, who tries to save diligently for her children's better future. At present, she is able to save a meager sum of Rs. 2,000 on a monthly basis, which is just not sufficient considering the rising prices. She intends to expand her business further into one that will self-sustainably increase her profits and provide a stable income.

She wants to make bulk purchases of stock like tea, chips, biscuits, chocolates, and water pouches. These items sell out quite soon and stocking them in small quantities is not efficient for her business. By purchasing them in bulk, she can negotiate better rates from her suppliers and save on making multiple trips to the market for buying these items. She will also be able to serve more customers, as currently, she has to turn them away when she runs out of stock. Overall, she stands to earn an extra Rs. 8,000, of which she will save Rs. 3,000 and invest the rest in further developing her tea stall.

Belonging to a socio-economically backward family, Rupaben she is not able to avail any loan from the local banks to carry out her business plans. Hence, she has formed a group along with four other industrious women with the support of the local non-profit organization Prayas and its partner Milaap in order to collectively seek a loan of Rs. 75,000. Sumitraben, Rekhaben, Mangaliben, and Harshaben run their respective microenterprises of selling garments, coal, fruits, and embroidery. 

Rupaben and the women in her group share the same vision and dream: improving their standards of living and providing the best education to their children. Your support will act as a ray of hope for these women.

loans.use: To buy in bulk stock like tea, chips, biscuits, chocolates, and water pouches to run her tea stall more efficiently

loans.name: Jay Khodiyar Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Kamuben (at center in the picture) is a representative of these women who are intent on writing their own destiny. A resident of Surendranagar in Gujarat, she helps her husband run their household of three by selling sarees in her community. But their monthly income of Rs. 10,000 is barely enough to meet their basic needs, let alone plan for any future contingencies. Kamuben’s undying spirit has motivated her to approach Milaap for a loan to grow her micro-enterprise. 

At the age of 42, Kamuben needs to rapidly grow her savings to meet her teen-aged child’s education costs; public college tuition is just a few years away. Having had no education due to her own parents’ impoverished status when she was a child, putting her own child through college is a big motivating factor for Kamuben in her business endeavors. In addition to this goal, Kamuben also needs to start building up savings for her and her husband’s retirement. Given that she contributes up to 60% of their collective earnings and has the potential to increase this contribution, she has taken on the onus for this. She wants to grow her business into a self-sustaining source of income that will help them weather the increases in costs of living and medical expenses as the years pass. She does not want to be a burden on her child in her old age. 

Motivated by these goals, she plans to increase her stock of sarees, buying them in bulk and greater variety. She will negotiate better rates from her suppliers, save on trips to the market, and cater to more demand from her customers. She stands to net an additional Rs. 10,000 each month as an immediate consequence of making these investments. During the ongoing festive and auspicious wedding season, this amount could go up. It will triple her current savings, and still leave enough to reinvest in sustaining the business. Lack of access to capital, however, stops Kamuben from putting her plan into action. 

In the last few years, Milaap and its field partner, Prayas, have been advancing the cause of underserved families like Kamuben. Prayas helped her identify four other local women who could benefit from access to microcredit. A loan of Rs. 100,000 will help Kamuben, Hanshaben, and Jasuben to expand their saree business, Sonalben to invest in her glass show piece business, and Sitaben to diversify her fruit-selling enterprise.

loans.use: To expand her cloth-selling business by buying more sarees

loans.name: Anjali Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
32-year-old Somiben (at center in the picture) lives with her husband and two young children in Chandkheda, a neighborhood in the thriving city of Ahmedabad, Gujarat, in western India. The leader of this group, she sells ready-made garments as part of her clothes business. She makes trips to the larger wholesale markets to procure these garments at lower rates, and sells them to local customers at a profit. 

Since she lives in a residential area that is also near a developing business zone, there is enough demand to justify expanding her business. In particular, her customers seek urban wear like t-shirts, jeans, leggings, tops, and even kurtis or Indian tunics. By growing her inventory of these garments in size and variety, Somiben stands to enjoy a monthly increase of Rs. 8000 in her revenue and profits. Of this, she will take Rs. 2000 home as income and invest the rest back into the further development of her business. 

Somiben has a long term goal of converting her small scale business into a sustainable source of income. She wants to ensure that she and her husband are financially independent in their old age. Her greatest wish, however, is to provide both her children a full college education. She had to drop out after primary school due to economic constraints, so this wish is the strongest motivating factor for her. 

Currently, Somiben earns Rs. 6000 a month, almost matching what her husband brings in. She saves her husband’s entire income towards her children’s future and to cushion them during any emergencies. Their savings do not leave room to finance her business expansion plans. So she and four other women in her group, Shantaben and Nanduben, who have their clothing business, Bhavnaben, who sells vegetables, and Madhuben, who owns a toran business, seek to crowdfund the capital for their business expansion plans. They seek a loan of Rs. 65,000.

Your loan will not only help boost their business, but will also empower them to uplift their socio-economic condition, providing a secure future for their children. Somiben is particularly grateful for your support in making her goals and wishes a reality.

loans.use: to buy t-shirts, jeans, tops, leggings, and tunics as stock for growing her ready-made garments microenterprise

loans.name: Chamunda Mahila Mandal-1 Group

texts.en:
Maniben (seen at center in the photograph) comes from a small village in the Kutch district of Gujarat, in western India. To supplement her family income, Maniben has been running a masonry microenterprise, a part of the local construction industry, where she mostly makes centering structures – temporary structures that builders use as a frame to build arches and vaults of a housing structure. Hardworking Maniben builds these centering structures using wood blocks, bamboo, ropes, etc., and rents them out to local builders. Through her efforts and diligence, she has grown her small business over the years, keeping her family financially afloat and her children in school. 

At the late age of 46, Maniben shoulders the responsibility of a large family. She has seven children: two in primary school, and 5 teenagers. With so many children to feed and educate, she cannot expect her expenses to dwindle. Like women in many parts of rural India, she had little say in the number of children she would have; many factors govern this private decision. Maniben wants things to be different for her sons and daughters. She believes education will bring them the right to make choices and access opportunities for progress, and she wants to guarantee that her children receive a good education. The costs of ensuring this are high, and will soon be beyond the reach of her current savings of Rs. 4500 a month. 

So, she has decided to further grow her small scale business of renting and selling centering structures. For this, Maniben needs to purchase raw materials such as bamboos, ropes, wood blocks, etc. to build more centering structures. The ability to build and rent multiple centering structures at a time will let her cater to more customers. She will be able to almost double her monthly savings, and invest an equal amount in the further growth of her business. 

Seeking to fund these plans, she has formed a group with other local women entrepreneurs who fight the same adversary of socio-economic backwardness: Bauben, Puniben, Laxmiben, and Paruben also want to expand their own centering structure businesses. They collectively request a loan of Rs. 75,000. Your loan will help these women achieve their dreams of a better tomorrow for their children and families.

loans.use: To purchase materials, such as bamboo, rope, and wood required to build more centering structures in her construction microenterprise

loans.name: Dilip Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Chetana (featured at center in the picture) leads this group of women entrepreneurs from Chandkheda in Gujarat. She runs what is locally known as a ‘cutlery’ business, selling accessories and artificial jewelry to local women. The Rs. 2000 she earns accounts for 20% of her family’s income. She saves all of it and an extra Rs. 1000 towards providing for the education of her only child. The income her husband generates is used to cover her family’s living expenses. 

Due to poor socio-economic circumstances, Chetana had drop out after primary school. She has experienced firsthand how a lack of education limits access to opportunities for a better life. She wants to ensure that the best possible education is provided to her child. What hampers her aspirations is her financial condition. With a household savings of Rs. 3,000 she can barely ensure a better future for her family. 

Chetana has taken the matter into her own hands by deciding to grow her micro-enterprise so that finances do not become a barrier to her child’s future. She plans to purchase her 'cutlery' in bulk for business expansion. She will buy popular accessories, such as bangles, ear rings, rings, artificial ornaments, and bindis in larger quantities and varieties to attract more customers and increase sales. Along with her are four other women, Rina and Pushpa who run clothing businesses, Premila who owns a tailoring business, and Bhanu who owns a sari business. All her group members share a common goal of business expansion. 

Chetana and her group seeks a loan of Rs. 65,000. With the increase in their income, they can uplift themselves financially and socially and guarantee the best possible education for their children. Chetana is grateful for the support lenders like you will provide her towards achieving these goals.

loans.use: To scale up her inventory of accessories such as bangles, earrings, rings, artificial ornaments, and bindis for selling

loans.name: Sakhi Mahila Mandal-1 Group

texts.en:
Forty-five-year-old Gitaben (at the center of the photo) runs her own tiffin service in Dhrangadhra city in Gujarat. She supplies the city’s working class with ready packed lunches, earning Rs. 5,000 a month, which is 50% of her family’s income. She lives with her husband and their teen-aged child. After living expenses, she sets aside Rs. 2,000 in savings. 

Gitaben studied until secondary school and then dropped out owing to her family’s socio-economic situation. She wants a different future for her child, with hopes of ensuring a public college education. As she and her husband age, they also need to build a corpus and sustainable livelihood that will leave them self-sufficient and cared for. With these goals to fulfill, Gitaben has set out to grow her tiffin service micro enterprise. Given the factories, railway traffic, and archaeological sites in Dhrangadhra, there is no shortage of potential new customers. 

With adequate and timely capital to invest in her tiffin business, Gitaben can pay deposits and opt for serving large orders. She can invest in bulk produce and ingredients, catering to more individual customers and negotiating better rates with suppliers. There is potential to immediately start earning an extra Rs. 3,000 each month from her enterprise, which she can either take home as savings or reinvest in further growth. To access the capital she needs to carry out her plans, Gitaben has formed a group with two more local entrepreneurs who share the same goals. One of them runs a petty shop and the other a tiffin service. Together, they seek a loan of Rs. 60,000 to expand their respective micro enterprises. 

The loan will help Gitaben and the women in her group take the measures necessary to increase their incomes and provide better for their families and children. They will be able to grow their small businesses into self-sustaining income generators for their later years. Gitaben is grateful for this opportunity and your support.

loans.use: To grow her tiffin service and serve packed lunches to more customers for a better income

loans.name: Hastapir Mahila Mandal Group

texts.en:
Rukshana, the group leader (the lady in the center of the photo), hails from the Surendranagar district in Gujarat. She is married and has a young child. She runs her own small fruit selling business that she needs your support to expand. Her income of Rs. 4,000 helps her to supplement her family income by over 40%. But her income is just sufficient to leave them with a meager savings. She has done her primary schooling and understands the importance of education. She wants to provide a complete public college education and better healthcare for her child. 

For this reason, she wants to expand her micro enterprise by buying more fruits as well increasing the varieties of fruits that she sells. This will bring more customers and increase her income. Bulk purchases will also help her negotiate better rates and save on transportation, improving her profits. She stands to add an extra Rs. 5,000 each month to her earnings. Local banks, however, do not provide the microfinance Rukshana needs to expand her small business. 

So she has joined with four other local women who run similar small businesses and want to expand their enterprises. Her group includes Zubaidaben, who wants to expand her tea shop, Jarina and Zubaida, who want to grow their vegetable selling businesses, and Halima, who needs to develop her cutlery business. Rukshana and her group seek to crowdfund Rs. 65,000 as an enterprise development loan. 

The loan will help these women to expand their businesses, increase their income and provide a better quality of life for their children. This will provide them and their family with financial security and stability. Rukshana, in particular, is grateful and determined to make the best of this opportunity to provide her child with the education she believes will present a chance to uplift themselves out of poverty.

loans.use: To stock up on fruits like apples, grapes, bananas, pineapples, and oranges to add variety and efficiency to her fruit selling business

loans.name: Zohra

texts.en:
Zohra is aged 52, and she is a mother of five children living in Lahore, Pakistan. 

Zohra's husband has been running a general store in which he sells rice, sugar, cooking oil, detergent, soap, biscuits, etc. He manages his household necessities from his own store; as well his relatives like to purchase from his general store. He speaks with an even tone, which is impressive, and he easily wins the trust of others. Due to his behaviour and tone, he has built up very good relations with his customers. His general store is very famous in the town, and that is the reason his business runs well. Due to good relations, his sales have increased a lot, but he does not have sufficient stock to cope with the demand. 

Therefore, Zohra requested a loan for her husband so that he can buy more stock of wheat, rice, flour, pulses, soaps, shampoo, detergents, biscuits, etc. Zohra hopes that her husband will utilize the loan in a positive way; this amount will help him to cope with the demands of her family. Zohra thanks Kiva and field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy inventory for her husband's general store.

loans.name: Ligia Del Carmen

texts.es:
Ligia es una bella mujer de 62 años de edad, madre de 3 hijos, criada con unas muy buenas costumbres, desde el joven desarrollo una gran pasión y gusto por todo lo relacionado con la belleza.  

Inicio su etapa productiva realizando cursos y capacitaciones, hasta que un día se aventuró y decidió ir en busca de su propia clientela montando un negocio de salón de belleza en su hogar. 

Solicita un crédito para la compra de surtido pues también quiere vender productos para complementar sus servicios, como crema de manos, gel, productos capilares, tinturas para cabello, barnices. 

El crédito para ella será muy importante pues podrá abastecer su empresa completándola con todos los insumos necesarios para operar y ofrecer cualquier servicio que lleguen a solicitarle.

Su sueño es que su empresa progrese de la mano de Interactuar y tenga muchos clientes ya que será determinante porque dejo su hogar para aventurarse en la ciudad buscando un mejor futuro.
texts.en:
Ligia, 62, is a beautiful lady with 3 children, who was raised with good morals. 

She developed a great passion for all things related to beauty when she was young, and she began her productive years attending classes and training courses.  One day she took a chance and decided to seek clients of her own, opening a beauty salon in her home.

She is requesting a loan to purchase supplies, as she also wants to sell products to complement her services, such as hand cream, gel, hair products, hair coloring, and nail polish.

The loan will be very important for her, as she will be able to stock her business, furnishing it with all the supplies that are needed to operate and offer any service that may be requested.

Her dream is that her business will progress with the guidance of Interactuar, and that she will have many clients.  This will be key, as she has ventured forth from her home in search of a better future in the city.

loans.use: to purchase supplies such as hand cream, gel, hair products, hair coloring, and nail polish.

loans.name: Basheer

texts.en:
Basheer is a 32-year-old married man from Deir Al-Balah.  He is a father of two sons and three daughters.  He works as an employee in the public sector, where he gets a very low wage, and he also has a stall for selling kids' clothes.  This supports the family with a very good income. 

Basheer took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy a new collection of kids' clothes for the new season. By taking this loan, Basheer will be able to increase his sales and also his income.  Basheer appears in the photo while he was working

loans.use: to buy a new collection of kids' clothes for the new season.

loans.name: Samir

texts.en: Samir is a 20-year-old single man. He lives with his family in Agdas. He has been working in the agriculture sector for two years. He has a monthly income of 150 AZN. Samir grows vegetables and fruits in his garden. His mother also helps him. But he doesn't make enough of a living; he can not help his family with their troubles. Therefore, he wants to improve his business. Samir needs a 700 AZN loan to buy fertilizer, seeds and fruit trees to earn more revenue in the coming winter, which will help him support his family’s needs.Samir hopes lenders will help him.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seeds and fruit trees.

loans.name: Sami

texts.en:
Sami is a 21-year-old single man from Rafah city.  He is a university student specializing in Arabic literature. He would like to take the BA degree and find a job in the future as a teacher to help his family with part of their expenses. 

Sami took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy a new laptop for his study.  By taking this loan, Sami will be able to do his homework and write reports easily. Sami appears in the photo with his new laptop

loans.use: to buy a new laptop for his study.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 29 years old married man from a village near Khanyounis city. He lives with his wife in a simple house. He works as an employee in the public sector where he gets a low income. This is the only source of income for the family. Ahmad is also a student in a local college where he studies for a Master's in Law He wants to complete his studies and find a better job to improve the family living conditions.

Ahmad took a USD Murabha loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy a new laptop for his studies. By taking this loan, Ahmad will be able to do his homework and write reports easily.

Ahmad appears in the photo

loans.use: to buy a new laptop for his studies.

loans.name: Hoạt

texts.en:
Mrs Hoạt works in agriculture farming food. Hoạt has been involved in this business for more than 10 years.

Hoạt is 42 years old, and she is married with three children. Hoạt lives in Hoang Hoa district, a  rural town in Thanh Hoa province.

This is Hoạt's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

The main hardship that Hoạt faces in her life is not having a hygeinic latrine. She is requesting a loan to purchase sand, cement and bricks to build a toilet.

In the future, Hoạt hopes to make enough money to provide for her kids, and to remodel her house. She hopes for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase sand, cement and bricks to build a toilet.

loans.name: Luchadoras De Los Chajones Group

texts.es:
Luchadoras de los Chajones
Este dúo formado por doña Oralia de los Ángeles, quien es la líder del grupo nos cuenta que es casada, tiene 1 hijo, y desde hace 3 años tiene una venta de artículos de consumo diario y tambien posee una libreria, además vende frutas y verduras, solicita este crédito porque necesita surtir su negocio comprando mas mercadería porque la temporada donde ella puede vender mas se aserca, y muchos de sus clientes descansan y le piden muchas frutas, y golosinas de la época, ella además quiere comprar algunas cosas para su librería ya que también la época escolar se acerca y quieren útiles escolares para  los niños.
texts.en:
This group of two women is called the Luchadoras de los Chajones. The leader is Sra. Oralia de los Angeles who is married and has one child. For three years she has been selling basic groceries. She also sells office supplies, fruit, and vegetables. 

Now Oralia is seeking a loan to buy stock for her store as the season when she is most busy is approaching. Many of her customers take holidays and they ask for a lot of fruit and candy typical of the season. She also wishes to buy school supplies as the school semester is fast approaching and people will want to buy items for their children.

loans.use: buy school supplies, fruit, and food items

loans.name: Islam

texts.en:
Islam, 28, is married and has three sons. She has a secondary-school education. She works with her husband in a grocery store that sells food. 

Islam's family was affected by the last war in Gaza, and her house was damaged. She has applied for a loan to fix and paint the walls and install glass for the broken windows. 

She hopes to be able to provide her sons with the best living conditions. She is very grateful to everyone who helps her.

loans.use: to fix and paint the walls and install glass in the broken windows.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia is a 65-year-old resident of Baybay, Leyte. The province of Leyte is known for coconut wine production. Her husband is a coconut farmer and from him, Virginia learned the business of selling coconut wine to meet the demand in the market and to earn a living. She started this business eight years ago. Virginia is asking a loan to buy more coconut wine and plastic containers from other farmers to be fermented and sold as vinegar. Virginia hope to expand her business so she can save for their future financial needs. Her income will provide herself and her husband a healthy diet and the means to reinvest in the same business.

loans.use: to buy more coconut wine and plastic containers

loans.name: Egleceria

texts.en:
Egleceria is a married woman with three children aged 14, 10 and 5 years old. She engages in a hog raising business. She raises and sells hogs to earn a living.  It has been already ten years that she has been engaged in the hog raising business. Together with her family, she lives in Mcarthur, Leyte. Her husband earns a living by engaging in farming. 

She is asking for a loan to purchase additional pigs. In this way, she will be raising more hogs in a few months to come. She will be earning more and will probably start to pay her daily obligations. Egleceria could now prepare healthy food for her family.

She dreams to expand her business to make it profitable and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase additional pigs

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en:
Roberto is a married man with nine children from Dulag, Leyte. His eldest child is 22 and the youngest is seven. 

He operates a motorcycle transport service locally known as habal-habal. It carries more than two passengers and travels from one place to remote ares. To augment his income, he raises and sells hogs. Almost 15 years now he has been engaged in that kind of business.

Roberto is asking for a loan of 20,000 PHP to buy piglets, pig feed and to repair his pig pen. These materials  are very helpful in his hog raising business. In this way, he will now raise and sell healthy hogs in a few months to come. His income will improve so that will enable him to provide his family with good food and continue sending his children to school.

In the future, he is hoping that he can manage both of his businesses properly for the improvement of their livelihood.

loans.use: to buy piglets, pig feed and to repair his pig pen

loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.en: Rodolfo is a hard-working man. He is 62 years old and from the town of Baybay, Leyte. He is married with an eighteen-year-old son. Rodolfo raises hogs for a living. This business started four years ago. He is asking for a loan of 10,000 PHP to buy piglets and feed. Healthy hogs have been attributed to quality feed and are more profitable to sell. His income will allow him to buy healthy meals for his family. In the future, he hopes to expand his business and make it a success.

loans.use: to buy piglets and feed

loans.name: Lynward

texts.en:
Lynward is a resident of Baybay, Leyte. He is 42 years old. He is married with seven children who are still dependents. Lynward owned a Sari-sari (variety) store and a passenger vehicle for five years now.  These businesses support the needs of his family specially his children. He is asking a loan of 40000 PHP to buy recapable tire and merchandise such as canned goods, detergent, candies, chips, snacks and soft drinks.

In the future, he dreams of business expansion for his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: to buy recapable tire and merchandise such as canned goods, detergent, candies, chips, snacks and soft drinks

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha is 57 years old, and lives in D'ban, Calamba, Philippines. She is married to a manual laborer and blessed with four children. Editha is engaged in retailing dressed chicken and has been doing this type of work for 10 years.

Editha became a member of Paglaum Cooperatives in June 2001. She is very thankful because she become a member of Paglaum at the time when her business down and they trusted her with an amount which she used to restart her business. As of now, Editha is applying for the amount of 50,000 PHP. She will use it to buy additional stocks of dressed chicken because of the season.

Editha hopes and prays, that her business will grow, and she plans to expand into a sari-sari store in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional stock of dressed chicken.

loans.name: Adoracion

texts.en:
Her name is Adoracion, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Regalado, a farmer, and she is a mother of four children. She manages their household while operating the business. She and her husband work hard to continually provide income for their daily needs.

Adoracion owns a farm. She grows crops on their farm located in Silang. The Philippines is still primarily an agricultural country despite the plan to make it an industrialized economy by 2000. Most citizens still live in rural areas and support themselves through agriculture. 

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 17,000 loan, which she will use to buy fertilizer and farm inputs for her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given her.

Adoracion aims to expand her business by buying another lot for her farm. She dreams of being able to send all her children to college. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

 * All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for fertilizer and farm inputs.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Her name is Merlinda and she is a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Primitivo, a farmer, and is the mother of two children. She manages their own household while operating the business. She and her husband work hard to continually provide income for their daily needs

Merlinda has a vegetable and fruit stand for a number of years already. To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 11,000 loan which she will use to buy different kinds of fruits and vegetables such as bananas, papayas and lanzones from a wholesaler which she sells at retail. She expects a higher demand of her fruits and veggies this Holiday season. She thanks God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given her.

Merlinda aims to expand her business to improve her income. She dreams of being able to send all her children to college. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for more vegetables and fruits needed in her business.

loans.name: Mary Claire

texts.en:
Mary Claire is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF to buy more items to sell in her general store.

Mary Claire has been in this business for two years. Mary Claire earns more income from food vending.

Mary Claire has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and  expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Ernie

texts.en:
Ernie is 42 years old and married. 

Ernie is in the agricultural business, raising livestock in the Philippines. Ernie requested a PHP 19,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for his livestock.

Ernie has been raising livestock for 15 years now, and has borrowed 10 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

Ernie would like to save enough to provide a secure future for his family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her livestock

loans.name: Luna Lee

texts.en:
Luna Lee is 38 years old and married with four children who are in school. She works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stocks to sell like noodles, sugar, soft drinks, etc.

Luna Lee has been in this business for ten years.

In the future Luna Lee would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more stocks to sell like noodles, sugar, soft drinks, etc

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling mud crabs in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy more mud crabs to sell for her buy-and-sell mud crabs business.

Norma has been in this business for 10 years. Norma earns more income from pig fattening.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Norma has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional mud crabs to sell

loans.name: Mamerto

texts.en:
Mamerto is single and has a buy-and-sell rice business in the Philippines. He has been in this business for 15 years now. Mamerto works hard to support his parents and his nephews for the education.

He has requested a loan of 24,000 Philippine pesos through the Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell.

In the future, Mamerto would like to save enough to buy more farm land.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Rosalia works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from fishing.  Rosalia is borrowing 15,000 PHP through NWTF to  buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc., to sell in her general store business.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Rosalia has been sustaining her business activities through her past 25 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy works hard to support her family. She is married and has a business buying and selling household goods in the Philippines.

She requested an 18,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell like foam, glassware and kitchenware. Daisy has been in this business for 9 years now. She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her business.

In the future, Daisy would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell like foam, glassware and kitchenware.

loans.name: Katiba

texts.en:
This is Katiba's second loan from Kiva. With the requested money she opened the grocery store and started serving the clients herself. 

Nowadays she has her own loyal customers, but her business needs some investment to be more productive for Katiba and her family. 

She requires help for purchasing an additional stock of products in order to offer a wide assortment that will satisfy her customers' needs and also to have money for working capital. 

The store is a significant source of income for this four-member family, and they will be really grateful for Kiva lenders' help for second time. 

Katiba will do her best to make steady payments on the loan. She awaits your support and kindness.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of products for her grocery store

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine is 29 years old and single she works very hard to generate additional income to help her parents.

Geraldine runs a prepaid mobile load in the Philippines and requested a PHP 7,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more mobile load to sell.

Geraldine has been in this business for five years.

In the future Geraldine would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more mobile load to sell

loans.name: Anahit

texts.en:
Anahit lives in Vanadzor city of Lori region. She lives with her husband and son. Her daughter is married and she lives with her family separately.
Anahit graduated from Vanadzor State Pedagogical Institute. She says that great love towards her profession of a pedagogue through many years keeps her in the same school. She has a 35 years of working experience in the field. At the school she is a teacher of Armenian Language and Literature. She also gives paid private courses of preparing the pupils for the entrance examination. 
She will be greatly happy to have Kiva lenders’ support, since she wants to buy a computer and also some studying manuals which she greatly needs during her courses.

loans.use: to buy a computer and also some studying manuals which she greatly needs during her courses

loans.name: Ayah Group

texts.en:
Ayah applied for a previous loan from Kiva lenders. The group consists of the same women from that first loan and is applying for a concurrent loan of 190,000 YER from Kiva lenders.

Roqia is the leader of the group. She applied for the first loan from Kiva lenders to buy more clothes and food for resale. In truth, that loan helped her very much for increasing her business. Roqia thanks Kiva lenders for their first loan. She hasn’t yet completely returned the first loan but is applying for a loan of 50,000 YER from Kiva lenders to purchase perfumes and incense to resale alongside the clothes, to attract more customers. She hopes this loan will be funded too.

loans.use: to buy perfumes and incense for resale along with clothes

loans.name: Razan

texts.en:
Razan is 22 years old and single. She lives in Al Salt with the rest of her family.

Razan is studying to become a teacher. She is in her fourth and last year at university. She is applying for a 1,500 JOD through National Microfinance Bank to pay her tuition for the coming semester. She is looking forward to graduating and helping her family with expenses.

loans.use: to pay her tuition for the coming semester.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy different kinds of phone accessories and recharge cards to sell in his store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more of  women's and children's clothes for resale, hoping to expand her business mor

loans.name: Lorenzo

texts.es:
Lorenzo es una persona casada de 33 años de edad vive junto a dos hijos y su esposa en una comunidad de Solola. 

Lorenzo es una persona muy conocido en su comunidad y lugares circunvecinos, pues él trabajo de Lorenzo es maestro de obra, pues con los años de experiencia que él lleva, el se encarga de elaboración de planes, presupuestos supervisar, coordinar y ejecutar construcciones tanto de viviendas y otros trabajos relacionados con la albañilería.

Lorenzo ama mucho a su familia y cada día busca la manera de cómo darles una mejor comodidad, pues él ha decido con su esposa en buscar un préstamo para ampliar su vivienda, ya que para ellos es necesario que sus hijos tengan una vivienda más digna donde vivir. 
La meta de Lorenzo es conseguir el préstamo, para empezar hacer realidad sus sueño en tan corto tiempo.
texts.en:
Lorenzo, 33, is married and lives with his two children and his wife in a community in Sololá.  He's a very well-known person in his community and the surrounding areas because he's a master carpenter with years of experience.  He's responsible for making plans, budgets, supervising, coordinating, and carrying out home construction and bricklaying jobs.

Lorenzo loves his family a lot and tries every day to find a way to give them greater comfort.  That's why he and his wife decided to get a loan to expand their house.  They need their children to have a better home to live in.

Lorenzo's goal is to get the loan and begin making his dream come true very shortly.

loans.use: to expand his home

loans.name: Sofije

texts.en:
Sofije is 47 years old and married with three children ranging in age from 17 to 22 with one of them, a daughter, being born mentally challenged.

Sofije is seeking your compassion to lend to her a loan in the amount of 100,000. Albanian Lek to take her daughter to a health specialist.

Sofije lives in rural south-central Albania where she practices agriculture and livestock farming to earn a living, whereas her husband receives a disability income because he was born with some sort of mental and physical disability. She’s got a dairy cow, sheep and chickens and sells only cottage cheese and salted butter at the farmer’s market in their vicinity. The fresh produce such as wheat, corn, peppers, tomatoes and beans that she produces she doesn't sell. In addition to the above, she’s got orchards from where she sells fruits as well including apples, figs, berries and plums.

loans.use: to take her daughter who was born mentally challenged to the health specialist

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to repair her husband's taxi.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her beauty parlor business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy creams, hair brushes, and other accessories for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Shefkije

texts.en:
Shefkije is 31 years old and the mother of three children between the ages of 4 and 10 years old. They live in a small village that is very poor and has a strong tradition of agricultural work as the main source of their economy. As with others, she keeps sheep, goats and lambs, currently having almost 30 animals that she cares for and tends to. She and her husband are able to sell the milk and the milk products in the market. Sometimes she even sells the sheep for more income once they are ready. She also has a greenhouse, where she plants different vegetables primarily for her family’s consumption and to cut expenses but to sell if necessary as well. She is a very hardworking woman, doing everything she can to offer and provide her children with anything that they need. 

Shefkije is very satisfied with this work being the main source of her family’s income. She has been in business for more than 12 years now. For the first time, she is requesting a loan in order to renovate her stable and purchase more lambs to further expand her farm. Her goal is to be able to continue with this type of business and generate more income and profit. She is very grateful for the support and thanks all of the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to renovate her stable and purchase more lambs to further expand her farm.

loans.name: Taw Ka Yan Shae Village Group

texts.en:
This community is located in Taw Ka Yan Shae Village in Myanmar's Ayeyarwaddy Delta region.  The Community Based Organization (CBO) consists of five committee members overseeing 30 village customers. This new loan would help the Taw Ka Yan Shae group members buy food for ducks (1 packet = $14, feeding 100 ducks for five days) and purchase more ducks. More ducks will increase the income from more duck eggs.

Pictured above are committee members from Taw Ka Yan Shae Village CBO, named Daw Mya, Daw Hla, U Kyaw, and U Chit.
 
Most of the villagers are farmers and do cropping as well as plant seasonal fruits such as melons and vegetables. Some of the men work as cycle carriers and for livestock, most raise pigs or cows. Daw Aye, included in the photo (First from left) is a 45-year-old farmer and her husband as well is a farmer. She lives together with four family members including two children. For income, she does cropping and her raises livestock too such as pigs and cows. Like other members, she plans to buy more food for ducks so that she will have more eggs to sell as well as more ducks.

loans.use: to purchase ducks as well as high-quality feed.

borrowers.first_name: Taw Ka Yan Shae Village Group

loans.name: Juan Albeiro

texts.es:
Juan en su búsqueda por un futuro prometedor y unas buenas oportunidades para salir adelante, decidió iniciar un negocio que según él le dará todo eso que siempre ha soñado.

Montara un negocio de tienda de abarrotes en el municipio de Uramita, con el cual planea sostener a su familia compuesta por su hija de 8 meses y su esposa.

Su principal dificultad es la falta de capital para trabajar.

Para lograr esto necesita la ayuda de un préstamo con la Corporación Interactuar que le permita comprar un enfriador, estanterías, vitrinas y surtido de productos básicos de la canasta familiar como abarrotes, granos, galletas y otros alimentos para abastecer e iniciar su negocio.

Apoya a los sueños emprendedores de un Colombiano con un préstamo hoy!
texts.en:
Juan, who is seeking a promising future and some good opportunities to advance, has decided to initiate a business that, he says, will give him all that he has always aspired to.

Juan is opening a grocery store in the municipality of Uramita by means of which he hopes to support his family, composed of his wife and eight-month-old daughter. His principal difficulty is the lack of working capital.

To achieve this he needs the help of a loan through the Interactuar Corporation, allowing him to buy a fryer, shelves, glass display cases, and a selection of  products from the basic family basket, such as groceries, grain, cookies, and other foods to stock and initiate his business. 

Help fulfill the enterprising dreams of a Colombian with a loan today!

loans.use: purchase a fryer, shelves, glass display cases, and a selection of basic products from the family basket.

loans.name: Motiana

texts.en:
Motiana is a 52-year-old mother with 1 child. She runs a small business of selling taro and bananas in her village to earn a living. She has been doing this for more than 3 years. 

Motiana has requested a loan to buy taro roots, banana tubes, wheelbarrow, rake, shovel, water tank and hand gloves to help her run the business. She hopes to use her profit to expand her business and provide for her family's needs. She became a member of SPBD in 2014.

loans.use: to buy taro roots, banana tubes, wheelbarrow, rake, shovel, water tank and hand gloves.

loans.name: Jose Adonaldo

texts.es: José es un hombre casado de 45 años de edad que habita en vivienda propia junto a su esposa y sus 2 hijos de 19 y 15 años de edad. Él es un hombre que se gana la vida con su negocio de venta de productos lácteos, desde hace 10 años, además se desempeña como jornalero manteniendo la estabilidad económica de su familia. José desea encementar el corredor de su vivienda, ya que siente que el polvo está causando enfermedades respiratorias a su familia, por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en: arena, cemento, grava y mano de obra para encementar el piso del corredor de su vivienda.
texts.en:
José is a married man who is 45 years old and resides in his own home along with his wife and their two children, ages 19 and 15. He is a man who earns his living through his business of selling dairy products. José has been in this business for 10 years. In addition, he works as a day laborer so that he can maintain financial stability for his family.

José wants to lay down a concrete floor in the corridor of his home. He feels that the dust is causing his family to come down with respiratory illnesses. For this reason, he is requesting a loan from FUSAI so that he can invest in sand, cement, gravel, and labor in order to install a concrete floor in the corridor of his home.

loans.use: to pay for sand, cement, gravel, and labor in order to install a concrete floor in the corridor of his home.

loans.name: Eulalia

texts.en:
Eulalia is 60 years old and married. She lives in Lopez Jaena, Philippinnes. Eulalia is doing her gardening activities to earn a living, and she is also engaged in a hog raising business. She mastered doing this type of activity over twenty years. 

She joined Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative on August of 2012. She is hardworking and has a strong determination to pursue her goals to sustain her needs, alleviating poverty. 

Eulalia requested a loan to purchase additional piglets and garden herbicides. This will greatly help her to boost her income. Someday, she hopes to buy a parcel of agricultural land to expand and improve her business. 

She is now supporting her granddaughter with her college education.

loans.use: to purchase additional piglets and garden herbicides.

loans.name: Aisa

texts.en:
Aisa is 20 years old and is single. She is living with her parents and three siblings in Mangidkid, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. 

She is earning a profit through her "tuba" (coconut wine) vending, and she is also working in swine production to generate additional income. This is how she helps her parents in sustaining their day to day survival.

Aisa joined Paglaum to learn about insurance and financial assistance. She is a responsible daughter who has a strong determination to pursue her goals. 

Someday, she hopes to continue her college education and have a stable job for her family.

loans.use: to buy bags of gestating feeds for her swine.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita used a previous loan to expand her recycling center. The loan also helped her pay for her children's tuition and meet other ongoing expenses. She believes that she can improve her business with a new loan for 10,000 PHP, which she will use to buy more scrap and recyclable materials to sell. Teresita will use her profits to meet both her family's needs and her goal of giving her children the best possible education so that they can have rewarding and successful lives. She meets weekly with *co-fellowship members to share stories of her work and draw strength and inspiration from her religion.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study religion, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for recyclable materials for business.

loans.name: Leony

texts.en:
Leony is 37 years old, married, and has four children who are in school. 

She is in the agricultural business, farming rice in the Philippines. Leony requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Leony has been farming rice for 3 years now, and has borrowed 10 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Leony would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Brenda Aracely

texts.es:
Desde las  cuatro de la madrugada Brenda se levanta para preparar todos sus productos y estar desde muy temprano en el mismo lugar que ha albergado su negocio del cual ha podido brindarles a sus tres hijas educación, alimento y hogar, Brenda expresa que lo más importante para una persona que quiere superarse es tener las ganas de ser alguien. Y ese ha sido el ejemplo que les ha dado a sus hijas trabajar duro para ser alguien en la vida. Mientras Brenda oferta su producto en el mercado sus dos hijas mayores lo ofertan por las calles del mercado municipal.
